body:
It looks like this test is failing:

```
======================================================================
ERROR: Test backfilling example dags
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/tests/jobs.py", line 76, in test_backfill_examples
    job.run()
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/jobs.py", line 173, in run
    self._execute()
  File "/home/travis/build/apache/incubator-airflow/airflow/jobs.py", line 1030, in _execute
    raise AirflowException(err)
nose.proxy.AirflowException: ---------------------------------------------------
Some task instances failed:
{('example_passing_params_via_test_command', 'run_this', datetime.datetime(2016, 1, 1, 0, 0))}
---------------------------------------------------
BackfillJob is deadlocked. These tasks were unable to run:
{<TaskInstance: example_passing_params_via_test_command.also_run_this 2016-01-01 00:00:00 [None]>}
```

Perhaps it's related to these changes?
@criccomini addressed the import problem and added a small fix for AIRFLOW-175, if you wouldn't mind taking another quick look. No other changes. Thanks.

Please rebase and squash your commits. Don't forget to adhere to the commit guidelines.

@aoen Firstly, thanks for this great work. A couple of things:.

_Paused DAG checking now occurs at the task instance level in models.py instead of in jobs.py to consolidate the "should this task run" logic into one place_

I think this should happen at the DagRun level not at the task instance level. (Dag->DagRun Task->TaskInstance)

_To make things less confusing for users, force running a task will now override/ignore:
task instance's pool being full_

This is an operational issue. At a minimum I would like to see a "Pool is full. Please confirm"

_task instance is already queued_

What will happen with the queued instance?

_Failed tasks will no longer be considered "runnable", they must be force-run or cleared first from the UI to be run, just like successful tasks_

Nice!

_Future work_

_Parallelize task instance dependency checking._

I have some ideas about this. I think we can go below 1-2s loops on a single core and reducing the amount of queries significantly by having taskinstances update counters in the dagrun. The issue lies in the are_dependencies_met function that does aggregate queries for every task(!).
In addition please follow the commit guidelines (proper commit message plz etc).
Sorry I am not convinced. The "DAG" part is quite simple to add and we might hit current installations.
Can you please add a test? In addition please update you commit message to adhere to the commit guidelines. Then I can merge. Thanks.
@mistercrunch any remaining issues for you?

Some docs would be useful: 1) Update an .rst with how to use this stuff, and 2) doc strings for the classes would be good.

I think (1) might be addressed by AIRFLOW-159, so I'm OK if you want to wait until that JIRA to do the .rst update, but I think the doc strings would be helpful in this PR.
LGTM
This looks fantastic. I had a few minor nits, but structurally everything is perfect. If you make the tweaks, I'm ready to commit.

cc @r39132 @mistercrunch @artwr @aoen See comments in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-161. I'm opposed to having a Quoble-specific redirect in the UI, but if this were made generic, I think it'd be a useful way for operators to provide a link that would redirect to some external page.

Thoughts?
@criccomini Addressed the review comments, though Im not sure how I can do squash merge. I think one of the admins of this repo has to do it?

A note, @johnbodley, conn.literal is specific to the MySQLdb package. It feels like we should move this method to the MySQL_hook and raise not implemented in dbapi_hook.

@whummer 
It looks like the CLI automatically includes subdag clearing as part of the clear operation. It could be useful to add a toggle to the CLI as well, just to keep the UI and CLI in sync. I don't use subdags, so I cannot weigh in on whether it would be useful to ever run a clear that did not in-fact clear subdags. The behavior prior to your change always cleared subdags by default - your UI change made it possible to not clear subdags. Why would this be useful?

@asnir Thanks for the contribution! Before we can merge please provide a description in the PR, and squash your commits with proper messages as per guidelines. Thanks.

I do have some general remarks that might be smarter to discuss in person to align. My concerns lie in the fact that DagRuns do not seem to be really used and it seems to rely on TaskInstances. Also some divergence with the work I and @jlowin have been doing from a first review. 

(I do really like spinning of the dag handling in separate processes, dont get me wrong!)
A lot of good work here, thanks @plypaul. It does need some realignment with the current push toward DagRun centralization but I think a lot of the core ideas are compatible.
